{{refimprove|date=January 2013}} {|{{Infobox ship begin}} {{Infobox ship image |Ship image=[[File:Destroyer Nazario Sauro.jpg|300px]] |Ship caption=Italian destroyer ''Sauro'' }} {{Infobox ship class overview |Name=''Sauro'' class |Builders= |Operators={{navy|Kingdom of Italy}} |Class before={{sclass-|Sella|destroyer|4}} |Class after={{sclass-|Turbine|destroyer|4}} |Subclasses= |Cost= |Built range= |In service range= |In commission range=1927–1941 |Total ships building= |Total ships planned= |Total ships completed=4 |Total ships cancelled= |Total ships active= |Total ships laid up= |Total ships lost=4 |Total ships retired= |Total ships preserved= }} {{Infobox ship characteristics |Hide header= |Header caption= |Ship type=[[Destroyer]] |Ship displacement=*{{convert|1058|LT|t}} standard *{{convert|1600|LT|t}} full load |Ship length= {{convert|90.16|m|ftin|abbr=on}} |Ship beam= {{convert|9.2|m|ftin|abbr=on}} |Ship height= |Ship draught= {{convert|2.9|m|ftin|abbr=on}} |Ship depth= |Ship propulsion=*2 shaft Parsons type geared turbines *3 boilers *{{Convert|36000|hp|kW|-2|abbr=on}} |Ship speed= {{convert|35|kn|mph km/h|lk=in}} |Ship range= {{convert|2600|nmi|km|abbr=on|lk=in}} at {{convert|14|kn|mph km/h}} |Ship endurance= |Ship boats= |Ship complement=156 |Ship sensors= |Ship EW= |Ship armament=*4 × [[120 mm Italian naval gun#45-calibre Vickers Terni 1924|{{convert|120|mm|in|abbr=on}} guns]] (2×2)<ref>{{cite book |last=Campbell |first=John |authorlink= |title=Naval Weapons of World War Two |publisher=Naval Institute Press |edition= |date =1985 |location=Annapolis, Maryland |pages =335–338 |isbn =0-87021-459-4}}</ref> *2 × 40 mm pom-pom anti-aircraft guns *2 × 31.2 mm machine guns *6 × {{convert|533|mm|in|0|abbr=on}} [[torpedo tube]]s (2×3) *52 mines |Ship armour= |Ship notes= }} |} The '''''Sauro '' class''' were a group of [[destroyer]]s built for the [[Regia Marina|Italian Navy]] in the late 1920s. They were based in the [[Red Sea]] Italian colony of [[Eritrea]] and all fought in [[World War II]] being sunk during the [[East African Campaign (World War II)|East African Campaign]] in 1941.
These ships were an enlarged version of the {{sclass-|Sella|destroyer|1}}, with six rather than four torpedo tubes, a 60 cm increase in beam, and a new bridge structure.
==Ships== These ships formed the 3rd Squadrilla and were based in the Red Sea.
* {{ship|Italian destroyer|Cesare Battisti||2}} :Named after patriot [[Cesare Battisti (politician)|Cesare Battisti]], :built by Odero, Sestri Ponente, completed 13 April 1927. :Based in the Red Sea, Scuttled on 3 April 1941. * {{ship|Italian destroyer|Daniele Manin||2}} :Named after patriot [[Daniele Manin]], :built by CNQ Fiume, completed 1 March 1927. :Based in the Red Sea, she was sunk by aerial bombing on 3 April 1941. * {{ship|Italian destroyer|Francesco Nullo||2}} :Named after [[Francesco Nullo]], :built by CNQ Fiume, completed 15 April 1927. :She was beached 21 October 1940, on [[Harmil]] island following a [[Attack on Convoy BN 7|battle]] with {{HMS|Kimberley|F50|6}}. The next day she was destroyed by three [[RAF]] [[Bristol Blenheim]] bombers. * {{ship|Italian destroyer|Nazario Sauro||2}} :Named after Italian naval hero [[Nazario Sauro]], :built by Odero, Sestri Ponente. Completed 23 September 1926. :She was sunk 3 April 1941 by an Allied bombing.
==Operational history==
The destroyers were outfitted for colonial service, and by 1935 they were deployed in the naval base of [[Massawa]], [[Eritrea]].<ref>[http://www.marina.difesa.it/storia/almanacco/parte05/navi0518.asp ''Cacciatorpediniere Sauro''] {{it}}</ref> Italian's entry in World War II left [[Italian East Africa]] isolated from Italy.<ref>Etnasi, Fernando (2007). ''Otto milioni di baionette: in guerra con le suole di cartone''. EdUP, p. 72. ISBN 88-8421-170-0 {{it}}</ref>
===Attack on convoy BN 7=== The only appreciable action in which the destroyers were involved was the [[Attack on Convoy BN 7|attack on the Allied convoy BN 7]], on the first hours of 21 October 1940. ''Nullo'' and ''Sauro'', along with [[Leone-class destroyer|''Leone'' and ''Pantera'']] shelled the convoy and its escort, inflicting some splinter damage to the leading transport ship, and launched at least two torpedoes aimed at {{HMAS|Yarra|U77|6}}, which successfully dodged them.<ref>O'Hara, Vincent P. (2009). ''Struggle for the Middle Sea: the great navies at war in the Mediterranean theater, 1940-1945''. Naval Institute Press, p. 103. ISBN 1-59114-648-8</ref> The attack was nevertheless repulsed by the cruiser [[HMNZS Leander|HMS ''Leander'']], which fired 129 six-inch rounds on the Italian destroyers. While ''Sauro'' and the other destroyers successfully disengaged, ''Nullo'' was chased by the destroyer {{HMS|Kimberley|F50|6}} and forced to run aground on [[Harmil]] island, where she was later wrecked by [[Royal Air Force|RAF]] [[Blenheim bomber]]s. ''Kimberley'' took two hits on a boiler from coastal batteries, and had to be towed to [[Aden]] by HMS ''Leander''.
===End of the surviving units=== The three surviving destroyers remained at dock in Massawa until the very end of ground operations in East Africa. Their commander ordered them to steam out on 2 April 1941, for an almost suicidal attack on [[Port Sudan]]. The squadron was soon discovered by British air reconnaissance, and immediately bombed by land-based [[Fairey Swordfish|Swordfish]] aircraft from the [[aircraft carrier]] {{HMS|Eagle|1918|6}}. ''Battisti'' managed to reach the [[Arabian peninsula|Arabian coast]], where she was scuttled by her crew. ''Manin'' and ''Sauro'' kept firing their antiarcraft guns until they were sunk by the British planes.<ref>Jackson, Ashley (2006). ''The British Empire and the Second World War''. Continuum International Publishing Group, p. 283. ISBN 1-85285-417-0</ref>
